children.name: The data structures that we have seen so far have been linear: a collection of data put in line, in some way we access the data either by indexing (arrays) or by traversing the data structure (linked lists)
keywords: The data structures that we have seen so far have been linear: a collection of data put in line, in some way we access the data either by indexing (arrays) or by traversing the data structure (linked lists)

children.name: In this lecture we will look at the tree data structure:
keywords: In this lecture we will look at the tree data structure:

children.name: What is a tree, more precisely?
keywords: What is a tree, more precisely?

children.name: Trees are linked lists where each node can point to more than one “next” node, which are called its children. For example:
keywords: Trees are linked lists where each node can point to more than one “next” node, which are called its children. For example:

children.name: We usually draw trees without the pointer boxes and root pointer
keywords: We usually draw trees without the pointer boxes and root pointer

children.name: Useful terminology: Root is the head of the tree, the node from which every other node can be reached
keywords: Useful terminology: Root is the head of the tree, the node from which every other node can be reached

children.name: Leaf is a node that has no children
keywords: Leaf is a node that has no children

children.name: All the data structures we have seen so far have been linear
keywords: All the data structures we have seen so far have been linear
a collection of data put in line, in some way
we access the data either by indexing or by ...

children.name: A web browser needs to parse documents into tree data structures (DOM) in order to display them and react to user inputs
keywords: A web browser needs to parse documents into tree data structures (DOM) in order to display them and react to user inputs

children.name: Tree representations of data are very common: in text processing in compilers on the web (html, xml, json) in databases in file systems (and hierarchical systems more generally) etc.
keywords: Tree representations of data are very common: in text processing in compilers on the web (html, xml, json) in databases in file systems (and hierarchical systems more generally) etc.

children.name: The benefit of using trees is that we can have quicker access to elements than in linear data structures: following one pointer in a tree amounts to going forward a whole level of nodes.
keywords: The benefit of using trees is that we can have quicker access to elements than in linear data structures: following one pointer in a tree amounts to going forward a whole level of nodes.

children.name: We call a tree binary when each node in it has at most two children - we refer to the children as: left, right. We will focus on binary trees.
keywords: We call a tree binary when each node in it has at most two children - we refer to the children as: left, right. We will focus on binary trees.

children.name: Here is an implementation of binary tree nodes in Python:
keywords: Here is an implementation of binary tree nodes in Python:

children.name: The easiest way to create a tree is to start from its leaves.
keywords: The easiest way to create a tree is to start from its leaves.

children.name: We can reuse variables storing nodes which we have already connected to their parents, so equivalent code is:
keywords: We can reuse variables storing nodes which we have already connected to their parents, so equivalent code is:

children.name: We can also create the tree from its root. A top-down approach.
keywords: We can also create the tree from its root. A top-down approach.

children.name: In general, depending on the kind of the tree and the use we intend for it, we write functions for adding elements to it and we usually combine top-down and bottom-up
keywords: In general, depending on the kind of the tree and the use we intend for it, we write functions for adding elements to it and we usually combine top-down and bottom-up

children.name: How to access the data that is stored in a tree? - In a systematic way.
keywords: How to access the data that is stored in a tree? - In a systematic way.

children.name: In other words: how to traverse a tree? I.e. visit all its nodes.
keywords: In other words: how to traverse a tree? I.e. visit all its nodes.

children.name: We could go level-by-level, from the top, going through each level from left to right. Like writing in a book.
keywords: We could go level-by-level, from the top, going through each level from left to right. Like writing in a book.

children.name: We could start from the root, go left and traverse all the left subtree, then go right and traverse the right subtree; each subtree is traversed in the same way (root, left subtree, then right subtree)
keywords: We could start from the root, go left and traverse all the left subtree, then go right and traverse the right subtree; each subtree is traversed in the same way (root, left subtree, then right subtree)

children.name: What implementation does this bring to mind?
keywords: What implementation does this bring to mind?

children.name: As above, but root -> right -> left Something else entirely
keywords: As above, but root -> right -> left Something else entirely

children.name: Idea: pick one direction (e.g. left), and go through the whole tree on that direction; then, go through the whole subtree in the other direction. In each tree we follow the same idea.
keywords: Idea: pick one direction (e.g. left), and go through the whole tree on that direction; then, go through the whole subtree in the other direction. In each tree we follow the same idea.

children.name: This is called depth-first search, because we traverse the tree down (by going left) until we reach its leaves, then we backtrack and continue with the lowest right node that we have not traversed yet. What algorithm can we use for this?
keywords: This is called depth-first search, because we traverse the tree down (by going left) until we reach its leaves, then we backtrack and continue with the lowest right node that we have not traversed yet. What algorithm can we use for this?

children.name: A recursive one: we start from the root go left and recursively search left subtree go right and recursively search right subtree
keywords: A recursive one: we start from the root go left and recursively search left subtree go right and recursively search right subtree

children.name: Algorithm: start from the root recursively search left subtree recursively search right subtree
keywords: Algorithm: start from the root recursively search left subtree recursively search right subtree

keywords: go left (subtree with root 5) start from 5

keywords: go right (subtree with root 18) start from 18

children.name: goes through the nodes of the tree level-by-level and left-to-right
keywords: goes through the nodes of the tree level-by-level and left-to-right

children.name: The idea is to use a queue to store nodes that need to be visited
keywords: The idea is to use a queue to store nodes that need to be visited

children.name: Start with the root 2 Put all the children of 2 in a queue Then iteratively do the following: go to the next node in the queue dequeue it and enqueue all its children
keywords: Start with the root 2 Put all the children of 2 in a queue Then iteratively do the following: go to the next node in the queue dequeue it and enqueue all its children

keywords: Suppose that we search for 42 in this tree:

keywords: At first the queue q is empty. Then we enqueue t in it:

children.name: Next we dequeue the node and since its data is not equal to 42 we enqueue its children
keywords: Next we dequeue the node and since its data is not equal to 42 we enqueue its children

children.name: Finall Dequeue
keywords: Next we dequeue the node and since its data is not equal to 42 we enqueue its children

children.name: What would happen if we used a Stack instead of a Queue? I.e. push = enq, pop = deq
keywords: What would happen if we used a Stack instead of a Queue? I.e. push = enq, pop = deq

children.name: are binary trees whose nodes are ordered in a very specific way (the BST property)
keywords: are binary trees whose nodes are ordered in a very specific way (the BST property)

children.name: For any node t : all nodes on the left of t (i.e. the left child of t, and all its children, and all its children's children, etc.) have data values smaller than that of t. all nodes on the right of t (i.e. the right child of t and all its children, and all its children's children, etc.) have data values greater or equal than that of t.
keywords: For any node t : all nodes on the left of t (i.e. the left child of t, and all its children, and all its children's children, etc.) have data values smaller than that of t. all nodes on the right of t (i.e. the right child of t and all its children, and all its children's children, etc.) have data values greater or equal than that of t.

children.name: The BST discipline is useful for search elements in the tree - it basically allows us to do binary search. Other properties: where is the minimal element of the tree? the maximal one? how can we find how many times does an element occur? how many nodes do we need to look at before finding an element we are searching for, or figuring out it is not there?
keywords: The BST discipline is useful for search elements in the tree - it basically allows us to do binary search. Other properties: where is the minimal element of the tree? the maximal one? how can we find how many times does an element occur? how many nodes do we need to look at before finding an element we are searching for, or figuring out it is not there?

children.name: we start from the root of the tree since the value we are searching is greater than the value of the root, we move right now our node is 42 since the value we are searching is smaller than 42, we move left now our node is 9 since the value we are searching is in fact 9, we stop and return True, meaning that the element was found
keywords: we start from the root of the tree since the value we are searching is greater than the value of the root, we move right now our node is 42 since the value we are searching is smaller than 42, we move left now our node is 9 since the value we are searching is in fact 9, we stop and return True, meaning that the element was found

children.name: we start from the root of the tree since the value we are searching is greater than the value of the root, we move right now our node is 42 since the value we are searching is smaller than 42, we move left now our node is 9 since the value we are searching for is greater than 9, we move right now our node is 9, so we move right now our node is None, so we return False (i.e. 19 was not found)
keywords: we start from the root of the tree since the value we are searching is greater than the value of the root, we move right now our node is 42 since the value we are searching is smaller than 42, we move left now our node is 9 since the value we are searching for is greater than 9, we move right now our node is 9, so we move right now our node is None, so we return False (i.e. 19 was not found)

children.name: if the current node’s data is larger than d, then we need to insert in the left subtree. We check if there is a child on the left: if not, we insert the new node there, otherwise we move the pointer to the left child

children.name: is a little bit more involved. Because simply removing a node can break the tree and the BST discipline.
keywords: is a little bit more involved. Because simply removing a node can break the tree and the BST discipline.

children.name: We look at three cases: Removal of a leaf node Removal of a node with exactly 1 child Removal of a node with 2 children
keywords: We look at three cases: Removal of a leaf node Removal of a node with exactly 1 child Removal of a node with 2 children

children.name: Removing a node that has two children
keywords: Removing a node that has two children

children.name: Removing a node (call it ptr) with two children is done in 3 phases: 1.We find the node whose data is the next greatest-or-equal in the tree after ptr i.e. the node with the smallest value in the right subtree this can be found by moving right from ptr then moving only left until we reach None. call this node minRNode 2.we replace ptr.data with minRNode.data 3.we remove minRNode
keywords: Removing a node (call it ptr) with two children is done in 3 phases: 1.We find the node whose data is the next greatest-or-equal in the tree after ptr i.e. the node with the smallest value in the right subtree this can be found by moving right from ptr then moving only left until we reach None. call this node minRNode 2.we replace ptr.data with minRNode.data 3.we remove minRNode

children.name: Could we have replaced with the maximal element in the left subtree?
keywords: Could we have replaced with the maximal element in the left subtree?

children.name: A few things we need to take care in the implementation of the remove function: the function takes as input the data to remove, not a node. So, it needs to first find the node to remove, if it exists, and then remove it removing a node requires to have a pointer to its parent, not the node itself (similar to removing from a linked list) the root node has no parent, so extra care is needed in order to remove it
keywords: A few things we need to take care in the implementation of the remove function: the function takes as input the data to remove, not a node. So, it needs to first find the node to remove, if it exists, and then remove it removing a node requires to have a pointer to its parent, not the node itself (similar to removing from a linked list) the root node has no parent, so extra care is needed in order to remove it
